name: Against Malaria Foundation
mission: We help protect people from malaria We fund long-lasting insecticidal nets LLINs and work with distribution partners to ensure they are used. We track and report on net use and impact.
theoryOfChange: The Against Malaria Foundation (AMF) has a detailed 'Our Process' page on its website that outlines its strategic framework. This document describes how AMF operates, from receiving funds to distributing long-lasting insecticidal nets (LLINs) and monitoring their impact. The process involves discussions with National Malaria Control Programmes (NMCPs) and other organizations to establish net need and accountability. AMF partners with in-country organizations for distribution and ensures rigorous monitoring and evaluation, including pre-distribution surveys, independent supervision during distribution, and post-distribution check-ups (PDCUs) to assess net usage and condition over time. AMF's approach is guided by principles of efficiency, transparency, and demonstrating impact, with a clear focus on measurable outcomes such as nets distributed, people protected, lives saved, and malaria cases averted.

evaluationSources: The Life You Can Save - Top Rated 2012 to 2025

dimension_explanations.alignment: With an alignment score of 22/50, the charity is recognized as a strong option for general sadaqah or humanitarian giving, though it lacks specific features tailored to Muslim donor preferences or religious frameworks [7].
dimension_explanations.impact: The foundation demonstrates moderate impact through its focus on capacity building and large-scale distribution logistics [3]. While it maintains a high Charity Navigator score of 94.0/100, the impact score of 24/50 reflects its role in procurement and monitoring rather than direct clinical outcomes [1][5].

baseline_narrative.headline: The Against Malaria Foundation (US) provides life-saving protection against malaria through the distribution and rigorous monitoring of long-lasting insecticidal nets.
strengths: Maintains a perfect 100.0% program expense ratio, ensuring all public donations fund net procurement [1][2]
Implements rigorous post-distribution check-ups (PDCUs) to monitor net usage and condition at 6 and 12-month intervals [5][6]
Exceptional fundraising efficiency with a cost of $0.00 per $1 raised [1]
baseline_narrative.summary: The Against Malaria Foundation (US) focuses on funding and distributing long-lasting insecticidal nets (LLINs) to protect populations at high risk of malaria [3]. In the most recent fiscal period, the organization reported a total revenue of $62,286,888 while maintaining a program expense ratio of 100.0% [1][2].

alignment.explanation: While the charity operates in <cite id="23">Muslim-majority regions</cite> like Guinea and Burkina Faso, it lacks specific religious alignment features.

rich_narrative.headline: The Against Malaria Foundation (US) provides life-saving protection against malaria through the distribution and rigorous monitoring of long-lasting insecticidal nets.

ideal_donor_profile.best_for_summary: Best for donors who prioritize extreme financial efficiency and want 100% of their contribution to go directly toward purchasing life-saving supplies.
donor_motivations: Want to ensure zero overhead is taken from their donation
Value rigorous, data-driven evidence of program success
Care about high-impact health interventions in the Global South
giving_considerations: The organization focuses on a single, highly effective intervention (nets)
Financial reserves are lower than industry averages
ideal_donor_profile.not_ideal_for: Donors seeking to fulfill zakat obligations or those looking for holistic community development beyond malaria prevention.

impact_evidence.evidence_grade_explanation: Grade A due to <cite id="21">verified evidence and outcomes</cite> and a strong, documented theory of change.
impact_evidence.theory_of_change_summary: AMF funds LLINs and works with partners to ensure they are used, tracking impact through <cite id="14">multi-year post-distribution check-ups</cite>.
impact_evidence.why_evidence_matters: Rigorous monitoring ensures that nets are not just delivered but are actually protecting families from mosquitoes.

long_term_outlook.room_for_funding_explanation: Malaria remains a leading cause of death in served regions, and <cite id="25">recent revenue declines</cite> suggest a significant funding gap.
strategic_priorities: Expand net distribution in DRC and South Sudan

peer_comparison.differentiator: Distinguished by its <cite id="4">100% public donation pass-through</cite> and <cite id="10">zero-cost fundraising</cite>.

similar_organizations.differentiator: Focuses more on advocacy and policy
similar_organizations.name: Malaria No More

strengths.detail: The organization maintains a <cite id="4">100.0% program expense ratio</cite> and a fundraising efficiency of <cite id="10">$0.00 per $1 raised</cite>, meaning no public donations are diverted to overhead.
AMF tracks outcomes through <cite id="11">smartphone survey processes</cite> and publishes detailed technical reports on <cite id="12">net repair and hanging status</cite>.
The foundation holds an <cite id="13">overall score of 94.0/100 from Charity Navigator</cite>, reflecting strong governance and transparency.

strengths_deep_dive: The foundation's operational model is built on extreme transparency and verification. By conducting <cite id="14">post-distribution check-ups (PDCUs)</cite>, the organization moves beyond 'nets shipped' to 'nets hung and used.' For example, technical reports detail the <cite id="15">categorization of holes in nets</cite> to determine when replacements are necessary. This level of granular data is supported by a <cite id="16">Platinum Seal of Transparency from Candid</cite>, their highest level of recognition for nonprofit disclosure.
rich_narrative.summary: The Against Malaria Foundation (US) is a highly specialized humanitarian organization dedicated to the <cite id="1">funding and distribution of long-lasting insecticidal nets (LLINs)</cite> to combat malaria in high-risk regions. <cite id="2">founded in 2003</cite>, the organization has established a reputation for extreme financial efficiency and rigorous data-driven monitoring. In the 2024 fiscal year, the foundation reported <cite id="3">total revenue of $62,286,888</cite>, all of which was derived from contributions. A defining characteristic of the organization is its commitment to a <cite id="4">100.0% program expense ratio</cite>, ensuring that every dollar donated by the public is used exclusively to purchase nets. This is made possible by private donors who cover all administrative and fundraising costs separately. The organization's operations are concentrated in <cite id="5">Africa, South America, and Asia</cite>, with significant active distributions in countries such as <cite id="6">Guinea, the Democratic Republic of Congo, and South Sudan</cite>. Beyond simple distribution, the foundation implements a <cite id="7">rigorous monitoring system</cite> that includes post-distribution check-ups (PDCUs) at 6, 12, 18, and 24-month intervals to track <cite id="8">net usage and hanging status</cite>. These evaluations involve <cite id="9">visiting thousands of households</cite> to assess the physical condition of nets and ensure they remain effective in preventing malaria transmission.
